TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit PrintControllerWithStatusDialog extends System.Drawing.Printing.PrintController

Docs.summary: Controls how a document is printed from a Windows Forms application.

remarks.format:
## Remarks This class implements a <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintController> and adds a status dialog box. A print controller specifies how a <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintDocument> is printed.
For a list of initial property values for an instance of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog> class, see the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog.%23ctor%2A> constructor.
For more information about printing with Windows Forms, see the <xref:System.Drawing.Printing> namespace overview. If you want to print from a Windows Presentation Foundation application, see the <xref:System.Printing> namespace.
## Examples The following code example shows how to create a new <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintController> and assign it to the <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintController> property. The example assumes that you have added the <xref:System.Drawing.Printing> namespace to the class and that you have created a new instance of a <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintDocument> as `myDocumentPrinter`.
[!code-cpp[Classic PrintControllerWithStatusDialog Example#1](~/samples/snippets/cpp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Classic PrintControllerWithStatusDialog Example/CPP/source.cpp#1)] [!code-csharp[Classic PrintControllerWithStatusDialog Example#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Classic PrintControllerWithStatusDialog Example/CS/source.cs#1)] [!code-vb[Classic PrintControllerWithStatusDialog Example#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Classic PrintControllerWithStatusDialog Example/VB/source.vb#1)]

Docs.param: A that represents the document currently being printed.
A that contains the event data.
Docs.summary: Completes the control sequence that determines when and how to print a page of a document.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog> class calls the <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintController.OnEndPage%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> method on the encapsulated <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintController>.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog.OnEndPage%2A> method is called immediately after the <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintDocument> raises the <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintDocument.PrintPage> event. If an exception is thrown inside a <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintDocument.PrintPage> event of a <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintDocument>, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog.OnEndPage%2A> is not called.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog.OnStartPrint%2A> method creates the <xref:System.Drawing.Graphics> object that is sent to the printer. After <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog.OnStartPrint%2A> is called, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog.OnStartPage%2A> method sets the <xref:System.Drawing.Graphics> object to a graphic of a single page. (Use <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog.OnStartPage%2A> to set how to print a page in a document. For example, you can adjust page settings separately for each page.) <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog.OnEndPage%2A> clears the <xref:System.Drawing.Graphics> object, while the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog.OnEndPrint%2A> method deallocates the object.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog> class calls the <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintController.OnEndPrint%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> method on the encapsulated <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintController>.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog.OnEndPrint%2A> method is called immediately after the <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintDocument> raises the <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintDocument.EndPrint> event.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog.OnStartPrint%2A> method creates the <xref:System.Drawing.Graphics> object that is sent to the printer. After <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog.OnStartPrint%2A> is called, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog.OnStartPage%2A> method sets the <xref:System.Drawing.Graphics> object to a graphic of a single page. (Use <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog.OnStartPrint%2A> to determine when and how to print a document. For example, you can delay printing for 30 minutes or adjust the printer settings for the document.) The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog.OnEndPage%2A> method clears the <xref:System.Drawing.Graphics> object, while <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog.OnEndPrint%2A> deallocates the object.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog> class calls the <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintController.OnStartPage%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> method on the encapsulated <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintController>.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog.OnStartPage%2A> method is called immediately before the <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintDocument> raises the <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintDocument.PrintPage> event.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog.OnStartPrint%2A> method creates the <xref:System.Drawing.Graphics> object that is sent to the printer. After <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog.OnStartPrint%2A> is called, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog.OnStartPage%2A> sets the <xref:System.Drawing.Graphics> object to a graphic of a single page. The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog.OnEndPage%2A> method clears the <xref:System.Drawing.Graphics> object, while the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog.OnEndPrint%2A> method deallocates the object.
Use <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog.OnStartPage%2A> to set how to print a page in a document. For example, you can adjust page settings separately for each page.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog> class calls the <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintController.OnStartPrint%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> method on the encapsulated <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintController>.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog.OnStartPrint%2A> method is called immediately after the <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintDocument> raises the <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintDocument.BeginPrint> event.
Use <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog.OnStartPrint%2A> to determine when and how to print a document. For example, you can delay printing for 30 minutes or adjust the printer settings for the document. <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog.OnStartPrint%2A> creates the <xref:System.Drawing.Graphics> object that is sent to the printer. After <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog.OnStartPrint%2A> is called, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog.OnStartPage%2A> method sets the <xref:System.Drawing.Graphics> object to a graphic of a single page. The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog.OnEndPage%2A> method clears the <xref:System.Drawing.Graphics> object, while the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog.OnEndPrint%2A> method deallocates the object.
<xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog.OnStartPrint%2A> is a good place to verify that <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrinterSettings> are valid.
